title: 109_hr5953
content: A commission called the "Commission for the Deployment of Hydrogen and Fuel Cells" is established. The Commission's duties are outlined in the Act. The Commission established is tasked with developing a strategic plan for mass commercialization of hydrogen as an energy source, utilizing resources from various sectors. It will also explore ways to maximize feedstocks for hydrogen production and recommend an entity to monitor progress. The Commission, composed of 8 members appointed by different leaders, must have at least 5 years of experience in science, technology, engineering, or public policy. Former Federal employees can also be appointed. The Commission, consisting of 8 members appointed by various leaders, must have at least 5 years of experience in relevant fields. Appointments should be made within 2 months of the Act's enactment, vacancies filled in the same manner, and members paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees serving on the Commission cannot receive additional compensation. Members are entitled to travel expenses. The Commission consists of 8 members appointed by various leaders with at least 5 years of relevant experience. Members receive travel expenses and a quorum is set at five members. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are elected by the members, with the Vice Chairperson appointed by a different political party. The Commission's staff includes experts and consultants. The Commission may appoint staff, including former Federal employees, in accordance with relevant civil service laws. They can also hire experts and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can provide personnel to the Commission upon request. The Commission can appoint staff, including former Federal employees, and hire experts and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Commission in carrying out its duties under this Act. The Commission has the power to appoint staff, hire experts, and receive assistance from Federal agencies. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, gather evidence, administer oaths, and obtain information from government agencies to fulfill its duties under this Act. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can also use the United States mails for official purposes. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to its investigations, with the Administrator of General Services providing administrative support services as needed. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence. If a person refuses to obey a subpoena, the Commission can seek a court order for compliance. Subpoenas must be served according to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Service of process for court applications under paragraph (2) can be done in the judicial district where the person to be served resides or can be found. The Commission is required to submit a report to Congress within 8 months of the Act's enactment, detailing its findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions.
